elements.text: PART ONE
1. NEWSREEL.
In a_ pastiche of those Pa the news _ bulletins, heroic, gung-ho and
thoroughly Fifties music starts to play as a background. The
commentator is a bit Bob Danvers-Walker... Hurrah!

It's” taken’ six years’ training, but the _ sky's’ the _ limit today as mankind sets out on its mission to see the stars. Crewman Donald Philpott, seen here waving to well-wishers, was chosen from _ over thirty recruits for the honour of being the first man to set foot on _ the Surface. At  a_ special reception, Crewman Philpott was presented to dignitaries from the Central Advisory Committee and got an_ extra special farewell from Ruby Craddock, this year's Miss Beetroot Factory. Whoops, steady on, Crewman. Better wipe that lipstick off your visor before’ the Missus_ sees. (Music swells’) And now we say God speed to you as you_ set off on Man's greatest endeavour... Fade as the music climaxes...
2. INSIDE CREWMAN PHILPOTT'S HELMET. We can hear the crewman's_ steady breathing as_ the MINISTER speaks to him from the other end of the phone line.

Good _ evening, Mr — Crewman. I'm speaking to you, on behalf of the Central Committee, in what must be the strangest telephone call ever*. In moments you will step out of your capsule, the first man _ to set foot on the Surface since our tiny world began. Strengthened by _ the finest technology the _ science factories can muster, you carry our future in your hands - our light into the endless dark’ Good luck, Crewman. We are praying for you.

Clunk of a_ phone being put down, followed by the _ dialling tone which fades. Philpott takes a deep breath, The buzz of a door opening. The enclosed sound vista opens out onto the wide, frozen surface of Mondas. A gentle moaning wind. Somehow we need to convey’ the absolute vastness of space around and above’ him.  Philpott's breathing quickens as he tries to take it in. He _ gives a_ single wailing scream and_ the perspective pulls back as it echoes across the landscape. *Direct quote from Nixon's message to Apollo u.
3. THE CITY - OUTSIDE THE PICTUREHOUSE. We are in a_ street of the underground city. But the place is deserted - no traffic, no people about. The DOCTOR and NYSSA are reading a poster.
(Bemused) Battle From Above The Sky. See visitors from
the stars. All Action Adventure. Thrilling. Astounding. Startling?
Sunday for seven days. Sounds suitably tawdry and
unrealistic. If we could find an usherette in the gloom, Nyssa, I'd buy you a strawberry mivwvie.
I thought 'the pictures’ meant a sort of art gallery.
Not exactly. But it is an entertainment... of sorts.
He rattles the closed doors.
DOCTOR And this cinema must have been shut for years.
boarded-up picturehouse doesn't prove this is Earth.
(Uneasy) You know, I'm not sure coming here was such a
good idea.
You didn't say much at all. Just that the coordinates
weren't right. This isn't Earth is it...? (Beat) Doctor?
(Beat) Everything shuttered up. Not a soul on the street.
Maybe there's a curfew. Or perhaps it's just late.
That clock said a quarter to eight. And the atmosphere's

stuffy. Like a hothouse. (Covering up) Yes. Yes, of course, it's Earth. We're right in the heart of London*. I just didn't recognise it under the _ street lights. Trafalgar Square is that way with the lighted tree. And _ that's’ the Palace beyond it. Must be Christmas.
(Sternly) Doctor...
Look, tram lines! Probably the nineteen-fifties. You see,
nothing to worry about at all.
Doctor, even I know that cities on Earth aren't built inside
huge stone caverns. And Earth certainly isn't an_ isolated’ grey planet, drifting light years from any star.
DOCTOR The atmosphere's frozen, hence the underground city.
And you must admit it looks like Earth.. down here at any sate.
This close to the Cherrybowl Nebula? Much too close, you
said.
I'm not sure. Can we go now?
You know where we are, don't you?
No. Not for certain’.
But you have a good idea.
DOCTOR To be honest Nyssa, I'd really rather not know. (Beat)
And yes, I know I'll never get another moment's peace if I don't find out. But I'm resigned to that. (Beat) Quite adamant, actually. (Double beat) Oh, all right. Just another half an hour.
I didn't say a word.
You go that way. I'll go this. But be careful. Just look.
Don't get involved.
All right. (Going) Half an hour. Back at the TARDIS.
Beat.
DOCTOR And I used to be such a good liar.
4. CITY STREET. A Cybermat  burbles past, diving for cover under a huge wobbly stack of timber. DAD HARTLEY and YVONNE are present in pursuit.
(Calling out) There he goes. Under the timber stack. Dad!
(Catching his breath) Hang on then. Crumbs Vonnie, I'm
getting past all this.
He's under there. Looked like a Deluxe.
Let's have a look. (Squinting under the timber) Oh, yes.
The Cybermat squeaks.
Deluxe Mark 6. Thinks he's safe holed up in there.
Here's the cheeser.
It's a sort of electronic rat trap.
Ta, love. Right, let's sort you out, you little silver vermin.
(Studying the cheeser) Now then, setting number oneU do for a little ‘un. He turns a dial.
Hurry up, Dad. The last tram’s’ gone already. It can't’ be far off Lights-out.
Not to worry. The patrols won't be out for ages yet.
Creak of unsteady timbers. The Cybermat squeaks.
Careful. You'll have the whole lot down.
places the cheeser on the planks.
Steady. It starts to hum.
There now. (Backs off a bit) He can't resist that. I'll give
him three minutes. Then we can be off home to tea. Got the _ net?*
Yep.
Good, lass. And here's the tongs.
The Cybermat squeaks again.
He's not budging.
Give him time.
Another Cybermat squeaks behind them.
What's that?
There's another blooming one behind us. Typical.
You don't think it's a nest.
The first Cybermat squeaks again. The second answers back.
Crafty little perishers. They're ganging up.
More squeaks. Then the second cybermat comes squealing across past DAD.
Look out!
Ow! Little bleeder!
The timber topples forward...
Dad!
And comes crashing down. YVONNE scrambles in.

Dad. It's all right. Dad? Don't worry, [I'll move this © stuff. (Pushing at the timber) Come on. Come on, move! (Gives up) No_ good? Look Dad, I'll go and get help. Dad? (Beat) Dad! (He's not moving) Oh,
God. Help! Someone, please help!
comes clambering over wood.
Hello? What's happening?
YVONNE The timber's across his chest. I can't lift it on my own.
She starts to cough.
What about you?
battles to unscrew a pill jar.
(Spluttering) Just need my pills, that's all. (Swallows)
There. Fine now. Please, my dad.
Let's look at him.
He's not moving.
We'll need something to lift the wood.
It isn't safe.
That metal rod. (Pulling) If I can...
The rod comes free.
Got it.
Be careful.
I'm going to lever up the wood. You try to pull him free.
Yep.
(Exerting pressure) Right. Here it comes. The timber starts to creak. Small bits clatter down.
It's lifting. Push harder!
(Struggling) I'm trying to.
That's it. Come on, Dad. (Pulling him clear) Out you come.
That's it. Come on, Dad. (Pulling him clear) Out you come.
Please... hurry
Nearly clear.
gasps. The timber clatters sideways.
Are you all right? Hello?
Beat.
(Coughing) Fine. Really. What about your father?
Dad? Come on, please. (Beat) I don't know. He's not
moving.
(Moving in) Let's see. (Beat) He's not breathing.
What are you doing?
Just a second. I can't find his pulse. (Beat)
I don't understand.
(Gently) I'm sorry... Look, I don't even know your name.
But your father... I don't think he's... well, he's not...
Her name's Yvonne, lass.
Oh!
Dad!
Gave us all a fright, that did. I'm a bit dusty, but still all in one piece.
Are you sure?
My arms’s a bit... No, course I'm fine. Now, who's your
friend?
I'm sorry. Your’ pulse.. I mean, I! thought you _ were...
I really couldn't've got Dad out on my own. Thank you...
erm...
My name's Nyssa.
(Laughing) Nyssa! Well, that's original. We're obliged to
you, Nyssa. Oh lor’, look at the state of your lovely clothes. We'd best get you cleaned up.
No. Really, I'm fine.
Well, you can't have far to go, not so close to Lights-out.
I'm not actually from around here, you see.
Sound of distant claxons. Plink as the street lights go out.
Lights-out. You'll never get home now.
I can look after myself.
(Laughs) With night patrols out? I reckon you'd best come
back with us. It's the least we can do.
Sorry, but I have to meet someone.
It's not safe after Lights-out. No one goes out.
Only blood-market spivs and civil servants.
(Foreboding) And the Police.
No, truly I have to meet...
(Sharp) Now then. No arguing, young lady. It's back home
quick as you can. And we'll see what's set for tea.
5. CITY STREET. The DOCTOR's solitary footsteps approach and stop.
(To himself) The Empress of China once had a great fright, She couldn't remember her left from her right... (Beat) Right,
I think... (Beat. Then reading) Tram stop. (Beat) Or maybe left. Ahhh... A shop door opens sounding its little bell.
We're closed.
Oh, I'm sorry. Just exploring.
Well, you won't catch a tram to go "exploring" from
around here at this time of the night. No more trams until the morning.°
Ah, well. I don't think I've ever travelled on a tram. I'm the Doctor by the way. How far does the city reach?
(Very cagey) Doctor, eh? Public or... private? (He makes
private’ sound deeply dubious)
That's between me and my clients.
Private, then.
Very possibly. Is that a problem?
We've a lot of doctors round here already.’ Where's your identity papers?
Sorry. Seem to have mislaid them.
Or your ration book? Any family?®
Lost them too. Very careless.
(Suddenly starts to chuckle) A doctorman. Yes, I like it.
Clothes, hair, teeth, eyes. Very nice. Very... healthy. All your they?
_Just something I go about in.
Outside and in?
Down to the last ligament. Strange. I heard artificial
organs were all the rage round here.
(Annoyed) Newfangled Committee gadgetry.
(Sharp) Committee? So, there's no more demand for good old-fashioned, natural transplants.
DODDOh, you should see my waiting list. You ever thought ofa
new career as a donor, Doctor? It can be very
Is this your shop? (Reads) Thomas Dodd, purveyor and
fitter of mecessary bodily parts. Discounts negotiable. Perhaps take a look.
(Worried) You a Health Inspector? You're certainly not Police.’
Tell me, Mr Dodd. Tell me about the City.
(Suddenly chummy) Listen, Doctor. How's about a glass
or three?’° We can have a nice little chat. Just us.
6. THE HARTLEYS' APARTMENT. Key in the front door. It opens to let in DAD, YVONNE and NYSSA.
(Calling) We're home, lad. (To others) In you come, you two. Let's see what our Prank's got for tea.
Thank you, but I really shouldn't...
Oh, nonsense. Yvonne, take Nyssa through while I lock
up.
own, are
I
lucrative.
should
He starts throwing bolts and jingling chains.
Through here, Nyssa.
She opens the door to the parlour.
Frank, we've got a visitor. Oh...
(Rather overbearing) Good evening, Yvonne.
(Wary) Sister Constant. Hullo.
FRANK The Sisterman's been waiting for hours. Where've you
been?
Don't exaggerate Frank. I've been waiting fifty-six minutes.
Who's that?
My name's Nyssa. Good evening.
(Coming in) Nyssa missed her last tram home. We
couldn't leave her out on the streets. You're out late, Sister.
Just on my _ rounds. (To NYSSA) Do I know_ you, dear?
I don't think so.
Nyssa's down from the South district. Not under your
jurisprudence up there, is she?
Regrettably not. How are you, Yvonne? Still employed at
the hydroponic culture plant?
Yes, thank you, Sister.
Good. And is the medication working?
Yes, thanks.
No side effects?
Nope. Not much.
Apart from being Dad's favourite.
Frank!
CONSTANT And you, Mr _ Hartley? How are you_ since’ the _ cardio- ectomy?
Well, normal mostly. Sometimes I can feel the Uttle
paddles going round in the chest unit.
That's normal.
Like being wired up to a blooming accordion. I'll give you
a tune if you like.
You seem to be holding your arm awkwardly.
Just pulled it a bit. Ow! (Winces)
Dad, you didn't say.
Perhaps we should take a look.
(Defensive) Oh, no. I know what that means. My arm's
fine. And I neither want nor can afford a new one.
As_ you_ like. (To NYSSA) And you, young’ lady? Nyssa what exactly?
Nyssa of Traken.
= O'Traken. That's unusual. There's an O'Brien’ family in the West district. May I see your papers?
(Prim) In the South, where I come from, we accept people
on trust. Mr Hartley has generously extended his hospitality to me. But I don't answer to_ strangers, especially public servant busybodies like you.
lets out a phew of disbelief:
(Very frosty) I see. Well, if you'll excuse me, I must be going.
Oh, dear. I'll see you out.
Sister? Any chance of a call-up?
(Weary) Oh no, Frank. Not now.
You're a_ bit young for that, aren't you? We'll have to see. Heaven bless you all.
After a second we hear the bolts outside the hall being undone.
_— (Whispering with glee~) Nyssa! That was brilliant. That
sorted the old boot out. Wasn't that brilliant, Frank?
(Sulking) Brilliant.
Surely if she can go, I can go too.
The front door closes. Bolts etc.
It's not _ safe. (Calls out) Dad, tell her — she can't go.
But my friend...
(Coming back) Put the kettle on, Frank. By heck Nyssa,
I wouldn't want to go a couple of rounds with you. But Vonnie's right. You're better off here.
I hope I wasn't rude.
DAD To the Sisterman? There's not much courtesy behind her
curtains, as my dad used to say. As for your friend... well, he'll just have to look after hisself.
7. PHONE BOX.

The apparatus is very old fashioned - Sixties style. CONSTANT is dialling a number. Two beats. We hear faint ringing. The line is answered. Faint du- du-du-du-du. A clunk as CONSTANT drops in a coin and presses button A.

It's Constant. I have a_ selectee at (very precise) North District Block Nine, Apartment Thirty-One - Hartley Nine Eight Dee. And I'm reporting a _ stranger at the same _ location. Check first mame Nyssa and the surname is something like O'Traken, possibly bogus. Warn all patrols to be on the lookout for any more unregistered strangers.
8. INT. SHOP.
FX: Pouring drink.
So, yes or no?
Sorry?
That drink.
Ah. No. Thank you.
Best not to hang about, then, Doctor. Curfew. Police'll be
round soon. They don't like people to be out after dark.
Mr Dodd, what is the population of the City these days?
Down to a few thousand.
DOCTOR And this is the last inhabited City on the planet?
(Cautious) On Mondas?
Course it is. Where've you been?"
(Glum) That's one question answered. No wonder
business is bad. You're nearly extinct. Doorbell as he opens the door.
Oi, where you going?
9. STREET.
The DOCTOR and DODD emerge and start walking.
You're not an escaped Cryo'speriment, are you? 'Cos you
can't refreeze once you're thawed out.
Sorry, I'm meeting a friend. And I'm late already.
(Short way off) Stop!
The POLICEMAN'S voice has the hard sing-song lilt not unlike, but not as extreme as, those of the _ first Cybermen of Mondas. The DOCTOR and
stop’ in’ their tracks. The electronic snort of a __ Cybersteed.
(Mutter) Committee Police?
Told you.
The horse starts to clip-clop slowly closer. It may _ have hydraulic _fetlocks too.
Remarkable. Unlike, but not unlike. And with a processed,
armoured horse too. The horse stops.
(Cautious) Good evening, officer.
Identify yourself. Civilian movement is forbidden during hours of curfew.
No blank mask yet. Still recognisably human for all the
augmented bodywork...
Identify yourself.
..but not as advanced as I'd anticipated. That's
encouraging. A whip lashes and cracks. The DOCTOR cries out in pain.
He says he's a doctorman.
(In pain) And this one says he's a paragon of virtue, but
I wouldn't believe either of us.
Stand up.
The DOCTOR rises with difficulty.
I was standing before you knocked me down... thank you,
officer.”
These streets are sealed. Present your Identification Papers.
I don't have an identity. Not as far as you're concerned.
Don't antagonise him.
I doubt he has the knack to get even slightly disgruntled.
(Slapping his pockets) Now, where did I put that Chinese cracker? (Finds it) Aha.
POLICED/IAN Do not move. Give your name and district.
The horse clip clops closer.
What're you doing?
Matches, matches... Just a small diversion.
Name and district are required.
He strikes a match.
Best kept away from animals.
Defiance is unacceptable. Surrender now.
(To himself) Whatever happened to resistance is useless?
(Aloud as he strikes another match) Sorry to keep you.
The firework starts to hiss. The whip cracks again. The DOCTOR yells in
pain again.
You are to be detained under the aegis of the Central Comm...
The firecracker starts to explode In a series of bangs. The horse shies.
Run!
The DOCTOR and DODD _ scarper. As the firework goes’ off, _ the Cyberpoliceman struggles to control its steed. But there is no emotion in its voice.
Warning... Warning. The horse calms.
Two _ suspects’ proceeding along ‘Third Street away from restricted area. I cannot leave my post. (Fade out) I cannot leave my post.
10. THE HARTLEYS' APARTMENT - FRONT ROOM.
Domestic bliss etc... and a_ caged _ bird twitters occasionally. I NYSSA's clearing china plates and cutlery.
Help clear the table, Frank. Don't leave it all to Nyssa.
I've got homework...
(Sarcy) Aahh. Too difficult, is it?
No. But J had to entertain the Sisterman.
She should be so lucky. Eric Krailford says...”
Oh, Eric Krailford. I saw Eric Krailford smooching with
Elsie Phipps in the turnip queue.
You little liar!
She was crying 'cos Eric's gone and...’*
Frank! We have a guest! Do your homework!
Beat.
What sort of homework is it?
(Superior) Logic and cybertechnics.”
Perhaps I could help. I know a lot about...
What?
Frank!
(Sulky) No, thanks.
Sorry.
Take no notice of him, Nyssa.
NYSSA The tea was very nice, Mr Hartley. Thank you. But J still
think I should go.
DAD And I've told you, it's not safe. Any road, we couldn't turn
you out. Not so close to the holiday. We'll see you get an early tram.
But it's not really like that.
(Whistles couple of notes) Trillerby's still not singing properly.
Stupid bird.
He used to pick up songs just like that. (To the bird) Come on, Trillerby. (Whistles again)"°
What sort of bird is he?
Trillerby Mark 2: But he's got a bit worn out.
Oh. (Half laughs) I thought he was real.
Real!
He is real, Frank. Half and _ half. Just a bit rusty, — that's all.
(Embarrassed) Yes. Of course.
The bird goes on tweeting.
Now, Nyssa, you're not grand, are you? Only if you're
technically minded...
What is it?
DAD The chest box, you see. Plays up something chronic at night.
If it's medical, my friend's a Doctor...
Not medical. Just a bit of technical jiggery pokery. And I thought maybe...
Can I see? Hold still.
Not something I'd bother the Sisterman with...
It's a bit primitive. Do you have a screwdriver?
A loud banging on the front door.
(Outside, terrified) Let me in! Help! Please! Help!"’ The banging continues.
Oh, no.
(Scared) Frank, quick. Turn on the telly.
Please! Help me! Help! Let me in! (Etc...)
The TV sound comes on - something that sounds very Fifties that we can have fun with.
Who is it?
Well, it's not carol singers. Just don't answer.
The WOMAN continues yelling and banging.
It's Mrs Ginsberg.
But we can't ignore her.
Louder, Frank.
The TV sound goes louder. So does the banging.
Daft woman. That's what happens if you're out after dark.
I've got to help her.
Nyssa, come back! A whip crack outside. The knocking stops. The WOMAN'S yells fade into the distance. The TV sound burbles on".
She's gone. Turn it off, lad. The sound goes off:
I don't understand. What's happened to her?
Don't touch the curtains.
pulls back the material.
Why are the windows boarded up? Outside the tramp of marching feet approaches.
(Afraid) Listen. The patrols.
Quiet. Must be Police.”
I said she shouldn't stay.
The marching is going past.
What is it? I don't want to get you in trouble.
The sound of an approaching heavy truck.
Whole bloomin' convoy of them. On manoeuvres at this
time of night? Now what are they playing at?
(Afraid) Dad.
Well, we don't want to know, do we? It's not our business. Put the kettle on, Frank, and then there's the holiday decorations to put up.
11. ENTRANCE TO AN ALLEY. Heavy trucks rumble past every few seconds. THOMAS DODD _ is from the shadows.
watching
Mr Dodd?
(Jumping) Strewth!
Are you following me?
(Relief) Oh Doctor. You gave the old paddles a turn.
Didn't know we were going the same way home.
What a coincidence. I was heading for the picturehouse
when these trucks appeared.
Watch it!
A particularly large truck lumbers past.
That was some sort of mechanical digger. Something's
going on under cover of darkness.”’ Yes?
Oh, yes. Never seen so many police. The whole area's
cordoned off, right down to the North Stalagstacks.
And?
Word is they're levelling the area for new parade
grounds.
Another truck thunders past.
So many of them. Let's take a look.
You can't. You'll never get through.
Don't say you don't know a back route, Mr Dodd. If the
trucks are going in empty, what'll they be bringing out? It won't be tea and cakes, that's for certain.
12. THE HARTLEYS' APARTMENT - FRONT ROOM. The family and NYSSA get out the decorations.
Here we are then. One tree.
Pworh. Dad!
Aye, well, maybe it's seen better days.”' But with a few baubles and a bit of tinsel... What d'you think, Nyssa?
(Unsure) It'll be like the tree in the square. What about
your chest unit? Is it better?
Humming along a treat now. You're a tonic, lass. Thank you.
I can't do homework with all this going on.
Then come and help with the washing up.”
Good riddance to bad rubbish.
Just don't nick all the baubles for earrings.”
plonks a box down and starts to rustle through the decorations.
Take no notice. Brothers are like that.
So I gather.
You'll be glad to get back to your family for the holiday.
(Very subdued) Yes, I'd really like that.
Oh, look. Here's the star for the top. I suppose you _ have a really posh tree at home.

Well, not really. Not like this. But at our autumn festival, when the leaves were turning amber, wed hang all the trees in the garden with paper lanterns. And all the fruits - all purple and red, were

carried in on _ silver panniers. And the people would sing at the gates. I used to love that.” YVONNE A whole garden of trees? The only real trees are in_ the hydrohouses where [I work. And _ the lit-up one in Committee Palace Square, of course.
Sorry, Yvonne. I like to imagine things.
Me too. I just want us all to be together again. Mum and Dad. Even Prank.
Yes. Mother and Father. And the Doctor too.
Don't worry about your friend.
I was thinking about that poor woman out there.
rustles decorations.
(Sharp) Taken into care, I expect. The Committee does whatever's for the best. Oh, look. It's Matty. He's been’ missing for ages.
(Rather revolted) What is it?
He's = my -= ~mat. He must’ have’ been _ hibernating in _ the decorations box.
But it's a metal worm.
Didn't you ever have one? They were the _ latest craze - ages ago. Matty? Come on, wake up. Matty?
It's alive, isn't it? Half machine.
Dad got him for me. Catching them's what he does. The mats that got away and went wild.”
Uncredulous) He's a mat-catcher?
Yep. Matty? Come on...
emits a sluggish meep.
No, he's not right.
Can I see? Perhaps I can fix him for you.
13. CHURCH TOWER. The DOCTOR and DODD climb the wooden stairs.
Up here's the church tower's clock room.
DOCTOR The Church of Former-Day Souls. I'm right behind you, Mr Dodd.
They reach the clock room - wooden floor.
This is it. Mind the workings in the dark.
These cogs are like mill-wheels. (Moves to the edge) Quite
a view though, if it was light.
DODD In daytime, you could see all the City from the bell tower,
before the Church got abandoned.
Like the picturehouse. Ah the old temples of worship
closing. (Craning out) Now, what’ are they up to down _ there?
Levelling the area. I told you.
Without touching the buildings? No, I think their purpose
is far more specific.
Why? What else could they possibly...*° (Horrified
realisation) Blimey, Doctor. They're digging up the graveyard. Footsteps behind them.
Careful. We have company.
Do not move. You are recognised escapees and are
required for adjudication.
14. THE HARTLEYS' APARTMENT - KITCHEN & FRONT ROOM. DAD and FRANK drying dishes.
She didn't eat much. Just picked at it. All our rations for the holiday going to waste.
We'll manage. Pass that dish.
You know what's happening, don't you?
What's that?”’
(Irritated) The manoeuvres, Dad. It's the final push. The work crews are on the verge of breaking through to _ the _— surface.
You know what I think about that. It's a long way off. If ever.
From the front room comes the sound of NYSSA and YVONNE laughing.
Dad?
Yes, Frankie.
I want to join up. There's no point in waiting for the call-
up papers. I want to be in there now, when the breakthrough comes. I want to see the sky and not go mad.
(Gently) That's very heroic, son. But you know the answer.
(Indignant) I'm not too young. And I'd send home my pay. DAD And we'd never see you again.
That's not true.
Name one person we know who's come back from the
work crews. Tom Reynolds? The Chang twins? I don't want to be proud of a_ black-bordered telegram with sympathy from the Central Committee. I want my son here.
(Under this) Mr Hartley? Yvonne and I thought...
Eric Krailford's joining up.
Eric? (Coming in) That's not true!
Yvonne.
Eric wouldn't!
Course it's not true.
It is true!
He wouldn't go. (Starts to cough) He wouldn't.
Yvonne...
Vonnie. Come on, love.
What's the matter with her?
(Spluttering) Just my pills. I'll be fine. Pills rattle from a jar.
There you are, sweetheart. Gently now.
What about me? You never listen to me! You look after
strangers and give them our rations. And _ nothing's left now from what you got when you sold Mum! He slams the door.”
Prank! (Exasperated beat) Nyssa, I'm so sorry.
No, please. Yvonne's more important.
(Weak) Much better already.
That's right.
Mr Hartley, I'm going now. I've caused enough trouble.
Oh Nyssa, no.
You mustn't stop me. I can look after myself.

PART ONE 1. Line changed to: ‘Strengthened by the finest technology the science factories can muster, you carry our future in your hands - our light into the

endless darkness.’ Marc Piatt (writer): 'I paraphrased Richard Nixon's words to the Apollo 11 astronauts from the recording in the BBC Sound Archives where I used to work. What Armstrong, Aldrin and Collins didn't know at the time was that Nixon also had another speech ready (not in Sound Archives) just in case the first moon landing was a disaster."

Line changed to: ‘We're right here in the heart of London.’ Marc Platt: ‘Since the Hartleys are obviously from "Up North", I thought the Doctor might pretend that the city was Leeds or Manchester, but he's much more familiar with the London area. Silurians, as Derbyshire's oldest residents, don't count as invaders.'

NOTES: PART ONE 1. Line changed to: ‘Strengthened by the finest technology the science factories can muster, you carry our future in your hands - our light into the
NOTES: endless darkness.’ Marc Piatt (writer): 'I paraphrased Richard Nixon's words to the Apollo 11 astronauts from the recording in the BBC Sound Archives where I used to work. What Armstrong, Aldrin and Collins didn't know at the time was that Nixon also had another speech ready (not in Sound Archives) just in case the first moon landing was a disaster."
NOTES: 2. Line changed to: ‘We're right here in the heart of London.’ Marc Platt: ‘Since the Hartleys are obviously from "Up North", I thought the Doctor might pretend that the city was Leeds or Manchester, but he's much more familiar with the London area. Apart from the Daleks venturing as far as Bedfordshire, and the Zygon clan north of the border, most aliens rarely invaded north of Watford. Silurians, as Derbyshire's oldest residents, don't count as invaders.'

NOTES: 8. Line changed to: "You got any family?’ Marc Platt: 'Dodd's fishing to see if anyone will try to trace the Doctor if he suddenly disappears. But the Doctor's response about carelessly losing his family might be another distant reference to my Doctor Who novel Lungbarrow. Or it could be to his other family, the companions, none of whom stay for long. The line's echoed by Nyssa's family memories later on. It also bolsters up the importance of tine Hartley family and how all families will soon be a thing of the past on Mondas.'
